conclusion: To determine when Object A and Object B meet, analyze their velocity-time graph and understand how their positions change over time.
The meeting point occurs when both objects have traveled the same distance from their starting point.
The graph shows the velocity (v) of Object A and Object B as a function of time (t).
Object A starts with a velocity v0 and its velocity decreases over time.
Object B starts from rest and its velocity increases over time, reaching v0 at t4.
At t1, Object A's velocity is decreasing.
At t2, Object A's velocity reaches zero, and Object B's velocity starts increasing.
At t3, Object B's velocity continues to increase.
At t4, Object B's velocity reaches v0.
The distance traveled by an object is the area under its velocity-time graph.
For Object A, the area under the curve from t0 to t2 represents the distance it travels.
For Object B, the area under the curve from t2 to t4 represents the distance it travels.
The objects meet when the distance traveled by Object A equals the distance traveled by Object B.
This occurs at the point where the areas under their respective curves are equal.
The graph shows that Object A and Object B have equal velocities at t2.
Since Object A's velocity decreases to zero at t2 and Object B's velocity starts increasing from zero at t2, they meet at this point.
The two objects meet at t2.
